boardgame.name: The Time Traveller
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Time Traveller is an adaptation of the Dr. Who television series to table-top role-playing. The system presented is a modified and adapted version of White Wolf's Storyteller System. Characters have Attributes which have Ratings numbered 0-6, which determines how many dice are in the pool for that Attribute. Attributes include Dexterity, Knowledge, Mechanical, Perception, Strength, and Technical. The player distributes 18 points (hence, dice) among them. Characters also have a list of Skills, with 24 points (hence, dice) divided among them. Characters purchase Advantages by spending Character Points. Finally, characters are equipped.

The HTML game is presented in two major sections: Rule Book and Supplements. There is little to differentiate the two entries--supplements tend to be lists of things. The Rule Book section includes: Game Mechanics, Character Creation, Template Types, Character Skill List, Special Ability List, Species List, Game Systems, and Combat Systems. The Supplements section includes: Merits & Flaws, Antagonist List, Biodata Extracts, Block-Transfer Rotes, Vehicles & Movement, and Equipment List.

boardgame.name: Bounty Hunter: 1881
boardgame.description:
The American southwest: 1881. The “iron horses” are operating in these parts regularly now, and the turn of the century is near. The rise of cities out here is clearly on the event horizon, as ever-increasing numbers of “civilized” easterners move in. Yep, the old ways are about to end. Still, law and order largely remain in their formative years. Wanted posters circulate throughout the region, and bounty hunters are plentiful….

In Bounty Hunter: 1881, you are one of these rough-and-tumble men. You’ll obtain wanted posters and travel by train, stagecoach and on horseback to get to outlaws’ hideouts. Once located, you’ll try to apprehend your quarry, by fair means or foul. Be aware, however, that bounty hunters start out with a bad reputation. If you bushwhack too many wrongdoers you’ll be considered just as bad — or even worse. You’ll also have to be careful when apprehending your prey, since most of them are quite capable of getting the draw on you! So saddle up, pard’ner and let’s make some money — bounty hunter style!

Game Play (simplified): After a quick setup, a player will choose one of several possible actions, usually selecting one of the three Travel cards on display at the bottom of the board, along with its associated bonus. These bonuses are, left to right: draw an Outlaw card, draw an On The Trail card, take a silver dollar from the display. Each type of card has a hand limit, and players may need to pay dollars in order to discard unwanted cards. Players travel to the location where an outlaw was last seen via Train cards, then play an On The Trail card along with the Travel shown cards on it to try to apprehend an Outlaw card in his hand, which is accomplished via rolls of the dice, and may be attempted by fair means or foul. If successful via the latter method, one or more Black Marks are taken, but there is a limit. Players can be wounded by their quarry and lose turns. The game ends when the Travel deck has been exhausted three times– so shuffle the discards after it runs out the first and second times. The rewards for the outlaws captured/ bushwhacked are totaled and $300 deducted from the player with more Black Marks. The player with the higher total wins.

boardgame.name: M12 Rules System: The Truth Is Out There
boardgame.description:
User summary:

In the M12 Rules System, characters have four Psychological Characteristics (Attributes) and four Physical Characteristics - the two groups each have Strength, Resistance, Manipulation, and Agility. Characteristics have a Dice Score of 2-6 (the rules support either pool purchase or randomization or array distribution). Characters have other traits defined such as State of Mind, Field of Expertise (very roughly analogous to a Class), and Skills. Skills have a Base Value which is a negative number that must be overcome before the character is considered "skilled". Skills are purchased from a large point pool resulting in highly skilled characters.

The M12 Rules System utilizes dice pools of D12 against a target number of successes. The dice pool size is determined by the relevant Characteristic's Dice Score. This is modified by the character's Skill rating (if appropriate) to find a resolution number which is compared against a Difficult Level.

The Truth Is Out There is a specific genre and setting for the M12 Rules System (apparently, the only one ever created). It adapts the X-Files television series to table-top role-playing. Characters are "Agents", investigating paranormal phenomena.
boardgame.rpg: M12 Rules System: The Truth Is Out There

boardgame.name: RONE
RONE: Krieger einer neuen Ära
boardgame.description:
RONE: Races of New Era is a strategic post-apocalyptic card game for 2 or 4 players. Players are immersed in a dark world full of destruction and suffering, a world where people are fighting to take back their place after a global nuclear war annihilated all achievements of the human race and all that was left was only a handful of usable resources. The remaining scattered groups of survivors are fighting amongst themselves for dominance over the remnants of the past. Now it is your turn to join the global war and recruit soldiers, battle machines, powerful hybrids, or tremendous mutants into your army. Equip your troops with the best available technologies and show all your enemies who is the ruler of the new order.

Players are represented in the game by their hero and play units or one-time effects (tactics) in an attempt to destroy all cards from the opponent’s deck. The number of cards in the deck and the player’s hand is connected to the number of health points of the player's hero. For each point of damage that the hero receives, the player has to destroy one of their cards – from the top of their deck or from their hand. Once a player loses all cards from their deck and hand they lose the game. Because each card used by a player during the game costs them a life point, players are forced to play cards as efficiently as possible so that each played card does more damage to the enemy than to themselves.

These combined mechanics create a well-balanced system where every erroneous move or unplanned action can lead to a player’s defeat. Each and every decision is tightly coupled, and even a small decision can completely change the course of the game.

Players have to find a balance between investing in game control, which allows them to play cards more effectively, or investing in killing the enemy hero, which is the primary goal. This means that players should control their damage output wisely. One can easily feed the enemy graveyard with destroyed cards, which may turn the game completely against them - because of the recycling system which allows players to put cards from the graveyard back on the battlefield. So, instead of dealing massive amounts of damage directly to the enemy hero, waiting sometimes has its benefits.

Timing of attacks, card activation, graveyard management and tactical decisions are the real keys to victory.

boardgame.name: Simple Campaigning
boardgame.description:
48-page A5 full colour booklet containing campaign frameworks for ancient and medieval warfare, which can be played as boardgames or as bases for miniatures battles. Includes Solo Campaigning (the rise of Rome), Angevin Empire, Across the Steppes (Mongol conquests), The Millennium Campaign (11th century Europe), Crisis of Rome (3rd century AD), The Wolf on the Fold (Assyrian Empire), The Calamitous Fourteenth Century (late medieval Europe).

Each of the seven games contains rules for re-creating the conflicts of a historical epoch and region, with counters on a map and using either a combat results table or miniatures. They vary widely in complexity; some have minimal rules and can be played very quickly, while others have detailed political and/or economic rules. The games are designed to entertain both historical boardgamers and miniatures buffs. Several can easily be played solitaire.

The point of each game is to determine by die rolls where conflicts arise, fight the battles and compare the outcome with history. Several include victory point tables so that players can measure their success against each other or, if playing solitaire, against the historical outcome - for example, can the player outdo the Lionheart and King John in holding the Angevin Empire together?

Some of the games can easily be completed in an hour, if using a combat results table; others take considerably longer, while all can last for many sessions if the battles are fought on the tabletop.

boardgame.name: Tipping Point
boardgame.description:
Have we found your Tipping Point? The high stakes quiz game the whole family can enjoy. Based on the highly popular TV game show, Tipping Point combines general knowledge questions and answers with nail-biting unpredictability.

Compete as teams or individuals. By answering questions correctly, players win tokens to drop into the electronic table top tipping point machine. Which of the four drop zone do you think will give you the biggest payout?

As the machine slides back and fourth, let your token fall and see whether that will start a chain reaction. One single correct answer could trigger a cashcade that changes everything!

Which team can amass the most counters to go forward and compete in the final jackpot round?

The show presented by Ben Shephard originally aired on ITV1 from 2012 until 2014 then on ITV since 2015.

boardgame.description:
The new Hide and Seek Audio excites the senses for a stimulating game of discovery.

Two ways to play:
Conventional game: The game comes with several boards, each depicting a scene scattered with various different objects. The objects are hidden within the images so that they mingle with the background, making them hard to spot. One of the boards is chosen for the game.

On each turn, a card is turned face up and players try to spot the object as fast as possible. The first one to do so wins the card. The winner is the player who accumulates the most cards.

With the DVD: Be the first (or play as a group) to find the animals and other things that correspond to the 30 sounds on the DVD.

boardgame.name: Twilight Citadel
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Two generations past a Paladin order of the God Tyr used the Twilight Citadel as a stronghold, which dominated the local trade route between the nations of Highwood and Stonewater. The two nations had always been rivals but were on relatively friendly terms joined in their common belief of Tyr. This was rent asunder when a new Lawful Good holy order, that of Athena came to the area and swiftly begun to convert the local population of Highwood to its side. This eventually led to a religious civil war in the region and the eventual separation of the lands into two camps of belief.

Geographically the two nations have been set apart by the Needle mountains an offshoot of the greater Spiral Peaks mountain chain. With only a few sparse trade routes thru them and no discernible passage otherwise, the few trade routes that did exist were important to both nations. Thus the Twilight citadel that sat upon a lone hill within a valley acted not only as a trade route monitor but also as the faiths headquarters in the region.

The civil war that swept the land some fifty years ago lead to the Citadel of the Tyrians being eventually besieged, breached and all therein slain. Once conquered the citadel quickly fell into disuse as the Athenians moved on in their solidification of their dominance of the faith of Highwood. Unfortunately one of the slain men of Tyr refused to take his journey to the afterlife and becoming consumed by the desire for revenge began to bring his hatred to bear on all those he considered as his enemy.

boardgame.name: The Tower of Boon Companions
Tower of Boon Companions
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

WhiteBox One-Shots is a line of short wilderness side treks, dungeon delves, and other brief encounters designed for compatibility with the Swords & Wizardry WhiteBox roleplaying game.

A tribe of orcs has moved into a ruined tower and begun raiding local villages. On its surface, it seems like a simple problem that any band of stalwart adventurers could handle. However, the tower was once an Adventurer's Guild outpost and is said to be haunted by the souls of fallen adventurers. Rumors also persist of long-forgotten treasures just waiting to be reclaimed. Can the party drive off the orcs and uncover the mystery of the Tower of Boon Companions?

The Tower of Boon Companions is a Swords & Wizardry WhiteBox adventure designed for 3-6 characters of 3rd-5th level (about 18 levels total). It is a site-based dungeon crawl with a number of different threats and challenges (some of which are class-based), so a variety of classes is recommended. Although vague references are made to the Chronicles of Amherth campaign setting, the adventure is designed to be dropped into any OSR campaign world.

boardgame.name: First Blood
boardgame.description:
User summary:

First Blood uses numerous elements of tabletop role-playing that will be familiar to experienced gamers. Actions involve rolling 2D6 and adding a modifier and then comparing the result to a Target Number, ranging from 2 (Automatic) through 8 (Serious) to 20 (Nearly Impossible). Resisted actions utilize an opponent roll in place of the Target Number. Combat uses initiative and other more involved mechanisms.

Characters have Body Attributes (Strength, Speed, and Dexterity) and Mind Attributes (Intelligence, Wits, and Charisma. Characters also have a variety of Skills. Most aspects of character generation can be either randomized or selected.

boardgame.name: StarCraft: Ghost
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




StarCraft: Ghost is a cancelled game previously under development by Blizzard Entertainment. Part of Blizzard's StarCraft series, the game was announced on September 20, 2002, and was to be developed by Nihilistic Software for the Nintendo GameCube, Xbox, and PlayStation 2 video game consoles. Several delays in development caused Blizzard to move back the release date and the game has not yet materialized. Nihilistic Software ceded development to Swingin' Ape Studios in 2004 before Blizzard bought the company, and plans for the GameCube version were cancelled in 2005.

Blizzard announced in March 2006 that the game was put on "indefinite hold" while the company investigated seventh generation video game console possibilities. The continued delay of Ghost had caused it to be labeled as vaporware, and it was ranked fifth in Wired News‍ '​ annual Vaporware Awards in 2005. In 2014, Blizzard president Mike Morhaime confirmed that Ghost was officially cancelled.

Unlike its real-time strategy predecessor StarCraft, Ghost is a third-person shooter, and was intended to give players a closer and more personal view of the StarCraft universe. Following Nova, a Terran psychic espionage operative called a "ghost", the game is set four years after the conclusion of StarCraft: Brood War and covers a conspiracy about a secretive military project conducted by Nova's superiors in the imperial Terran Dominion. Very little of the game's storyline has been released; however, in November 2006 after the game's postponement, a novel was published called StarCraft Ghost: Nova, which covers the backstory of the central character.

Source: Wikipedia, "StarCraft: Ghost", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Evil Clerics
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Let the Blasphemous Rite Begin!

Legendary Villains: Evil Clerics delves deeply into the lore and legendarium of the most devoted servants of the dark powers: evil clerics. Though not always a GM’s go-to villain, these malevolent mendicants and blasphemous bishops are plentiful in fantasy games. Myriad options in the form of archetypes and domains already exist, but this book goes further in exploring the roles evil clerics can play as villains in a campaign. This book includes dozens of new feats, spells, and archetypes specially designed for evil clerics, as well as the disease domain and sinweaver prestige class, providing a wealth of options for augmenting existing cleric class features. In addition, it provides all-new options like the avatar of evil family of feats that bring an evil cleric one step closer to dreadful divinity, variant channeling feats to enrich an evil cleric's bag of supernatural tricks, and the Craft Cursed Item feat gives mischievous clerics a new way to torment their victims. Finally, this book contains a collection of malicious magic items like the altar of binding and phylactery of heresy, some to augment the armamentarium of an evil apostle and others to bedevil those who would stand in her way, along with a pair of perilous priestly tomes replete with dark secrets, sinister spells, and other nefarious new options to make your cultists and clerics truly memorable foes.

Grab this 40-page testament to the power of the dark side of divinity, and as if evil clerics weren't enough you can make your most malevolent masters of evil even more marvelous with the companion books Legendary Villains: Antipaladins and Legendary Villains: Dark Druids! It's time to Make Your Villains Legendary!

boardgame.name: Mythic Erinyes and Horned Devils
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Worst Hell Has To Offer!

The erinyes and the horned devil are perhaps the most terrifying and iconic devils, representing both the fallen angel, in the form of the cruel and torturous erinyes, and the classic devilish imagery of a bat-winged, horned, oversized muscular humanoid, in the form of the chained devil. Despite this, neither of these two great infernal warriors received any mythic treatment in Pathfinder Roleplaying Game: Mythic Adventures.

This book presents game statistics for the mythic erinyes (CR 10), which projects an aura of truth that painfully punishes all those who lie within its presence, can keep victims alive long after they should be dead, and can even torture a creature so thoroughly that if it returns to life after being killed by the mythic erinyes, it does her bidding. It also presents statistics for the mythic horned devil (CR 20). These fiends can wrap their spiked chains around a victim’s throat, using the chain like a leash to magically control their victim. Their chain can also rend a victim’s very soul, along with its body, and much, much more. boardgame.name: Johnsonville: Cutthroat Capitalism
boardgame.description:
Referred to by the publishers as a "role-playing party game", Johnsonville: Cutthroat Capitalism is a dice-rolling thematic game set in a small 1950s town.

Players start with a small pool of money that may be depleted every turn, and the object of the game is to have completed the most "citizenly tasks" (objectives drawn at the start of the game) by the time all other players have lost money. Player interference to deplete the money of other players is encouraged.

Actions in the game can be completed in two ways- through rolling against the Game Master, or "Johnson", or by drawing "Kit Cards", fictional cure-all products. Players interact by describing actions and rolling or drawing to attempt to complete them. The positive(or negative) effects of these attempts are described by the Johnson in a humorous fashion based on the numbers rolled or card drawn.

boardgame.name: Ten
步步归十
boardgame.description:
The number 10 is the focus of the game. To score ten, each player has a beautiful set of wooden tiles scoring values from 1 to 3.
The players take alternate turns to place their tiles in the game field. The rows become longer and grow in all directions. Who will be the first player to create a series of personal tiles to score a total of 10?
TEN is a simple, but strategic connection game when players must constantly keep an eye on the opponent’s row of tiles.
Seeing the bigger picture, risk-taking and a little luck are needed to score 10. There are two versions of the rules, so players can test their luck a little more or less.

listing.notes:
Spieleranzahl: 2 bis 2 Spieldauer: 15 Minuten Altersempfehlung: 8+
TEN - Zehn gewinnt! Die Zahl 10 ist das Ziel. Um es zu erreichen, steht jedem Spieler ein Satz schöner Holzsteine mit den Werten von 1 – 3 zur Verfügung. Im Wechsel legen die Spieler ihre Steine ins Feld. Die Reihen werden länger und wachsen in alle Richtungen. Wem gelingt es als Erstem, die eigenen Steine so aneinanderzureihen, dass deren Summe 10 ergibt? TEN ist einfaches und zugleich raffiniertes Legespiel bei dem man die gegnerischen Reihen stets im Auge behalten muss. Guter Überblick, Risikofreude und eine Portion Glück sind nötig, um die 10 vollzumachen. Die Regel beinhaltet zwei Versionen, in denen das Glück mal mehr, mal weniger stark ins Geschehen eingreift.

boardgame.name: Labyronia RPG
boardgame.description:
Synopsis

Labyronia is a traditional, story-driven RPG focused on partly non-linear progression and exploration in a large and original world. Advancing in the world and puzzle solving requires critical thinking at times, even though most puzzles and environmental hazards are fairly simple to overcome. The game's core challenges lie in overcoming certain large rough road maps, and surviving the strategic boss battles on the way. To gain more skills, the player must utilize the super-simple, but elegant Cue system. The storyline starts slowly, but should be emotion-inducing.

A brief introduction

The Labyrinths. Maze-like structures consisting of trees, rocks, hills and everything in nature. The Four Elemental Gods- Labyronia's rulers- created the Labyrinths by using their divine might. Soon afterwards, powerful monsters appeared, beginning to cause havoc in the world.

Fifty years have passed since the Labyrinths first came to be. Why were they created? Did the gods really want to punish the people for their wickedness? What about those monsters? They seem to have originated after the Labyrinths appeared. It's time to stop pondering this and go out there to find out the truth myself! This will be the final chapter of my diary, at least for now.

-Diary of Arres

Features & Version Info


Partly non-linear progression in a large and original world.



The Cue system encourages exploration. Find abnormalities to obtain skills, and challenge yourself to collect all the Cues!



Strategic Boss battles, and smooth combat system with Yanfly's battle engine.



Random battles are limited to the world map (and even there it's possible to avoid them usually.) Otherwise, all enemies are visible.



Clean, colorful visuals and a bunch of fresh-looking monsters.



Experience the emotional storyline and challenge the four elemental gods!


Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Labyronia RPG 2
boardgame.description:
Synopsis

Labyronia 2 is a traditional, story-driven RPG, mainly focused on a strong atmosphere. The story takes place in a dark, icy fantasy world, and contains horror elements.
The progression through the maps and objectives is mostly linear, but optional secrets are hidden in certain maps. Advancing and puzzle solving may require critical thinking at times.
The game has a simple turn-based battle system, and a skill-collecting system via Arms Manuals and Spellbooks. These items can be found from the secret areas of the game, or bought from certain stores. Playing the first Labyronia is not required to understand Labyronia 2, since the overaching storyline can be obtained through the course of the game.

Story

10 years have passed since the hero of Labyronia fulfilled the Dark Prophecy.

Labyronia, a warring world once ruled by four gods of the four elements. To gain absolute power over the unruly nations, the four gods used their might to create the Labyrinths: maze-like structures formed from bits of surrounding nature. To achieve this, they used a magical item called the Pendant of Labyronia, which was said to be of divine origin.
After the people had spent a few years getting lost in the messed up new world, a bunch of monsters appeared. Without further ado, they started to wreck every place (no questions asked) including the capital of the world and the place where those gods were hanging out!
Unfortunately the gods had a plan to counter these monsters, and of course they had to go and execute it. This is where things got even worse. It's all got to do with this guy called Arres, and how we gave a good beating to both the monsters and those smug gods! This led to an event followed by the state we're now in...

The world has gone cold, and dark. Seriously, there's no clear spot up on the sky from the clouds. I need to scrape frost from my whiskers every morning! Additionally, there are freaking ghosts out there, trying to kill everyone not looking at race or gender. Believe me, you do not want to stick with these guys... 'cause they are gonna stick on you! If we can't resolve this situation with haste, i'm a bit worried that this world might experience the opposite of "heat death", and it ain't gonna take long! So, it's time to start doing something about it.
First, I need to go see Windir. He used to be a god after all...

-Garic's diary, final page

Features

-Discover the hugely atmospheric world of Labyronia during its final days.

-Learn new skills by reading Arms Manuals and Spellbooks. Explore the world to find hidden skills!

-Yanfly's Visual Battler system provides enjoyable combat.

-Recolored and revamped tilesets and graphics to offer an original look.

-Solve puzzles and overcome environmental hazards ranging from easy to demanding.

-Experience the dark and emotional storyline in a world of fantasy and horror.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Labyronia Tales: Legend of Mysteria
Legend of Mysteria
Legend of Mysteria RPG
Murder in Mysteria
boardgame.description:
Game Manual

In the ancient tower of Mysteria, wizards ruled the world of Labyronia. The first leader of the Order, Zemocon, had pioneered gaining divine powers. According to old prophecies, one day four gods would reign equally, governing the four elements.

Something in Labyronia was however changing. It was first noticed by the Council of the highest ranking wizards. A strange malice was spreading in the world, and rumors of war emerged. The wizards felt powerless, deciding to hold a meeting to address the situation.

And so, the wizards gathered in the great Assembly Hall. Red robed mages of fire, blue robed mages of water, brown and green-garbed earth mages and air mages in purple cloaks stepped into the hall each one in their turn, to face the Head of the Council, Dinyon. Suddenly, something unforeseen happened.

An assassin shot an arrow, and it pierced Dinyon. "I'm... bleeding", the great wizard muttered. Before the members of the Council were able to react, Dinyon suddenly vanished in a bright flash of light.
The assassin attempted to flee, but one of the wizards struck him down with a fireball. It appeared that the offender was not a wizard, but a normal human. Someone had hired him and brought him into the tower.
The red robed wizard grabbed the assassin, asking: "Who hired you?!" Drawing his last breath, the murderer whispered a name: Windir. Perplexed, the young air mage Windir tried to defend himself against this false accusation, but to no avail.

In the Assembly Hall, three of the most powerful wizards from each element were present at the time of the assassination. Who is the real perpetrator?

- The origin story to Labyronia Saga.

- Immerse yourself in the unprecedented gameplay: discover clues and information to unveil the secrets of the Wizard's Council.

- Nonlinear progression with mysterious puzzles and riddles: Your best weapon is your intelligence.

- Unusually dense world, with a great amount of things to do in every area.

- Learn the magical language of the mages, and figure out a way to the outer world to complete the quest.

- 12 suspects and two possible endings depending on your conclusion: Who killed Dinyon?

boardgame.name: Toast!
boardgame.description:
Update: Toast! was not funded on Kickstarter, but the design was taken up by Horrible Games and developed into Raise Your Goblets.

Toast! is themed around ruthless medieval nobles trying to poison each other during the toasts at a royal function. The King has decreed a bizarre etiquette to be followed, in an attempt to discourage this behaviour. However, instead it has just turned the practice into an art and a sport, with each (surviving) noble having developed a particular expertise.

In a round of play, goblets are arranged in a circle in the middle of the table, one in front of each player, such that players can’t see their contents. Players take turns to secretly place wine, poison or antidote tokens into the goblets, switching the goblets around, or using their characters special abilities. Each player has a target, and their aim is to ensure that, when the round is ended by someone calling for the Toast and the players all ‘drink’, their target’s goblet is poisoned and theirs is safe!

The game supports 2-12 players. The main rules are for 4-6 players, there are special rules to extend up to 12 players (where pairs of players play as a noble and their wine-taster), and there is a separate game mode for 2-3 players (a sort of Russian Roulette with goblets).

boardgame.name: Emotional IQ
boardgame.description:
How much of what you say is actually made up of your words?

Emotional IQ is a hilarious new party game for 2 players on up to party size groups. It’s easy to learn and easy to play. There are 2 types of cards: the Emotion Cards, and the Sentence Cards. You’ll choose 1 card from each stack and then deliver the sentence aloud for everyone to hear.

How do you say, “Great news everyone, I got engaged today” in your best sad voice? ...or... "That guy just sneezed all over you" in a voice full of Happiness?

Other players will have to guess which Emotion you are using. Here’s the catch – no one except you knows which Emotion card you drew, the Sentence and Emotion rarely match, and you only get 1 shot at your delivery.

It's a science experiment of your brain vs your mouth. Emotional IQ is designed by Bryan Sloan and illustrated by Roman Shipunov.

boardgame.name: Topoum
boardgame.description:
1916, Europe: The Great War has ravaged the land. Only one fertile ground remains and it is strongly disputed...by moles?

In Topoum, you control an army of moles that are fighting for control of a piece of fertile land in the middle of the Great War. The moles are well known for their blindness and, for this reason, you'll earn badges (points) if you can form uninterrupted lines of sight between your soldiers.

Topoum features several different types of cards of four categories: combat, movement, expansion and special. Each game is different because you build the playing deck with seven types of cards (+110.000 combinations!).

Each player has a private hand with two cards and there is a public row of five cards available for all the players on the board. This is the structure of the turn:


Choose between "Enter the Battle with a Mole" (playing one card is mandatory) or "Move Moles in the Battlefield" (playing a card is optional for each mole).
Score the lines of sight between your moles.
Refill the cards in your hand and the public row.


When the "Peace" card (hidden at the bottom part of the deck) is drawn, the game ends. The players now score extra badges for majorities and sets of the categories of the cards they used during the battle.

boardgame.name: Ukiyo Zoshi
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Ukiyo Zoshi was published as HTML in an unfinished state. The setting is partially and unevenly developed. The basic premise suggests several "factions" that vie for power and influence. The geographic setting consists of several "sectors" that connect to each other along defined pathways, all meeting at a central sector.

The action resolution system is referred to as the ISOMER System. It is presented as a standalone resolution mechanism using cards. Players flip a card and add their skill to the value, comparing this result against the game master's card flip added to a difficulty factor. In general, the card values swamp the modifiers making resolution mostly random. The rules favor narrative resolution whenever possible.

boardgame.name: Non-Combat Magical Items Deck
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is based on ongoing series of Non-Combat Magical Items from the Master Of Dungeons blog. Players love to receive magic items, and it's a great way to reward players for beating a dungeon, defeating a foe, or saving a village. However, too many magical +2 Lance of Goblin Explosion's can leave a party overpowered. This is especially true now in the world of Fifth Edition "Bounded Accuracy". There are 32 cards in the deck.

Some DMs have introduced something called "Mundane Magical Items" to their tables. These items aren't as strong as some of the glimmering, vibrating swords of the past, but they are still usually aimed towards a strong combat utility.

I've decided to take things a different direction at my table. In a magical world filled with dragons, genies, and portals to another dimension, I believe that there would be items that don't feel most at home on the battlefield. These items need not be only trivial magical implements like self-writing quills, or mirrors to help a dwarf with his self-esteem, they can rival the power of their magical sword and bow brethren.

As an added disclaimer, I don't refer to these items as "Non-Combat Magical Items" in front of my players. The title isn't so much a rule as it is a design philosophy.

These cards can be given to your players when they find an item, and can also be shuffled to add randomness to your loot.

Just because these aren't weapons or armour doesn't mean they aren't powerful, there are exceptionally strong items in here, like a sacrificial dagger that allows a user to absorb the powers of a dead god, or an amulet that prevents aging.

boardgame.name: '65: Squad-Level Combat in the Jungles of Vietnam
boardgame.description:
A squad-level, tactical game, ’65 recounts the early battles of the Vietnam War, from Ia Drang to Operation Starlight, and most everything between. The large and beautiful counters (1" to 1.375" square) represent squads, Leaders, Heroes, Snipers, M-48 and Pt-76 tanks, and more.

As these units’ commander you will move and fight over three geomorphic game boards as you try to best your opponent in one of eight, nail-biting historical scenarios. The game is card-driven, using a system similar to Flying Pig’s Night of Man, which adds a sense of delicious uncertainty to the play. “Can I advance my sappers or does the enemy have a fire card he's just waiting to play?" Furthermore, the cards simplify the game, containing much of the data needed to play. You won’t spend the afternoon with your head in a rule book when you play ’65. This is a game created by gamers for gamers to play.

Each Game Includes:

3 richly illustrated, 11” x 17” geomorphic game boards.
Over 175 HUGE 1” and 1.375” counters.
1 deck of 54 action cards.
Full color rules and scenario booklet.

boardgame.name: Stras
boardgame.description:
Here are the rules...

Give each player 10 cards (1 pack of card needed)

The winner is the one who get rid of all their cards first (jokers are free cards and are best to keep until the very end to surprise the other players)

You moove one dice at a time. Not like a combination. This will make you end up on 2 different square.

Avoid the "C" spot, if you end your move on one, You'll have to take another card in your hand.

If you end up on a square with a drawing of a dice, you have to moove your pawn by that number of square in any direction you want.

You can only moove one direction with the first dice no come and back. But you can choose to move back with the second dice in any direction. Or even use a different pawn for the second dice.

You need a 6 on one dice or on a combination of the 2 dices to put a pawn into play. You have tree role to get it otherwise you loose your turn.

If you got a 6 on one dice you can move your pawn by the number of the other dice. You can move on any direction.

You get rid of a card by ending your moove on a card symbol identical as your card. The card symbol count as a square. You can only enter that card symbol square by the exact number and by the only way make with an arrow. This is a safe square and the only place your safe to be eaten by an another player.

You get eaten by a player if they end up their moove on the same space as you.

boardgame.name: Console: Handheld
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

It's a game in your pocket!

This is a tiny, folded roleplaying game designed to emulate some of the original handheld RPGs. The rules are simple, the gameplay is condensed, and the graphics are pixelated. In two pages you get character creation, spells, equipment, monsters, some advice on how to play, and even a character sheet!

Print it out double-sided. Fold in half, then in half, then in half, keeping the game's title visible after each fold. Heck, you can even make copies and hand them out at your local gaming store! The whole thing is covered by a Creative Commons license, so as long as you don't sell it or remove the author's name, you can do whatever you want with it.

A little bit of nostalgia in an even smaller package.

boardgame.name: MountTen
テンガロン
boardgame.description:
In MountTen (テンガロン), players want to rid themselves of cards in hand first in order to win the round. The deck consists of green cards numbered 1-40 and red cards numbered 10-30. Players start with ten cards in hand with 2-3 players and eight cards with 4-6 players. Set the deck nearby with the top card revealed.

The start player plays any card to the center of the table. The next player must play a card at most ten lower or higher than this card, e.g., playing 14-34 if the 24 was lead. If the second-played card is lower (higher), then all subsequent cards must be lower (higher) — but also always within ten of the most recently played card. If a player cannot or doesn't want to play, they pass and draw the top card of the deck, then reveal the new top card. If all players pass in turn, then whoever played the most recent card clears the table and leads a new card.

Two exceptions:

1. If the next player in turn can play a green card exactly ten lower or higher than the topmost card on the pile (no matter the direction of play), that player can call "Mount Ten!", play the card, then clear the table and lead a new card.

2. If any player can play a red card exactly ten lower or higher than the topmost card on the pile (no matter the direction of play), that player can call "Mount Ten!", play the card, then clear the table and lead a new card.

When one player has no cards in hand, the round ends. Each player with cards in hand scores -1 for each green card and -2 for each red card; the player who went out scores positive points equal to all the negative points scored that round. Complete as many rounds as the number of players, with the start player rotating each round. Whoever then has the highest score wins!

boardgame.name: Vis Imperia Victoriana
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The 19th Century was the grand time of Empire. New lands could be annexed by working class soldiers ever eager to find a King’s ransom in loot. The sons of the middle-class could hope for a better life in Colonial service and the younger sons of ancient families could earn themselves a name and perhaps even lands of their own. These quests would take them across the worlds, exploring jungles and wastelands unknown to "civilised Man". Of course the people living in these foreign, "unexplored" lands might rightly be said to have a different view of these adventurers, merchants and empire builders suddenly turning up on their doorsteps.

Nevertheless, before science-fiction the prime adventure genre was the fiction of empire, full of men who patronised the natives as a class but who treasured the friendship of individuals; dissolute Europeans or crafty viziers for villains; lost cities, bandit tribes and the sort of place where a stiff-upper lip and the ability to ride well were damn near all a gentleman needed and, unless a plucky adventuress or a native princess taking pity on an imprisoned chap, women were hardly seen.

boardgame.name: VRAANZANNTH
boardgame.description:
User summary:

VRAANZANNTH is intended to be a generic, universal resolution mechanism for role-playing in any genre. The game uses an atypical dice method by rolling 1D12 and 2D6, with most results (except outright failure) being resolved with an action table.

Characters in the system have six Attributes: Strength, Reflex, Vitality, Personality, Mentality, and Vanity. Attributes typically range from +5 to -5. Vanity is also referred to as the "normalizer stat" and has three sub-values; it generally is used when something else don't seem to fit. Each Attribute covers a range of Skills, each Skill has a Points value. Attribute values and Skill Points are used as modifiers on action resolution dice rolls.

Version 2.0 presents a slightly more intelligible overview of the game rules as well as cleaned-up action tables and far fewer typographical errors from Version 1.0. Generally speaking, the two versions are interchangeable. Version 1.0 was titled VraanZannth.

boardgame.name: Wasteland Hero
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The post-holocaust genre has had good representation in science fiction literature. Most of the sources available were written, curiously enough, before World War II. The remainder seems to come from the cold war days of the mid-seventies into the early eighties. It has only met limited success as a role playing platform, all of the available games "out there" seem to support either World War III itself or else hundreds to thousands of years after the fall of civilization.

Wasteland HERO tends to be best played three to five generations after the final fall of civilization. The world is an ecological nightmare and very few life forms have survived intact. Of those species that survived, humans fared the best. They were ready for the devastation that they created. Their progeny, however, didn’t survive entirely intact. The integrity of the species was threatened spawning several new sub-species. As it turns out most of the "Neo-Earthers" were a product of the collapse of scientific ethics in the last days of man. The once familiar creatures of the earth were transformed into mighty beasts worthy of legend, and hostility quickly replaced serenity for the sake of survival in a barren world.

boardgame.description:
Cult of the Wind is a game about people who pretend to be airplanes.

"In an unknown time and place, a cult that worships the wreckage of ancient airplanes gathers to mimic the dogfights of old. With the peak of humanity far behind, their world is a mausoleum to a lush and verdant Art Deco past."

In Cult of the Wind, players compete and cooperate in ritualistic multi-player human dogfights, complete with imaginary weapons, pretend explosions, and airplane noises made with their mouths. Shower your friends in a hail of imaginary bullets and proclaim, "I got you! You have to lie down," to which they respond, "Nuh-uh, I have a shield." You argue about whether or not airplanes can have shields, meanwhile some other guy does a cannonball onto your head while whistling. It's great.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Mo Mo Toretore
モーモートレトレ
boardgame.description:
User summary
In the game of モーモートレトレ (Mo Mo Toretore), you are an alien Primary Schoolchild. During a school outing to the planet Earth, your teacher told you to capture cows in the field.

The teacher specifies how many cards you must play, and you play that number of cards. If the cards' total face value equals a cow's number, you can capture the cow. (Your arithmetic skills are tested because you are a Primary Schoolchild).

If you are the only one who played your number, you get the whole points, otherwise points are divided among players who played that number.

With cute illustrations, this card game can be enjoyed by all, from children to adults. This game is especially good for those who frequently play with Primary Schoolchildren or new gamers. The first edition is published in Japanese but English rules are available online.

Publisher's summary
モーモートレトレは、宇宙人の小学生となってウシを捕まえるのが目的のゲーム。
先生の指示の枚数のカードを使って手札の数字とウシの数字をあわせよう。（簡単な足し算引き算が必要です）
自分だけが出した数字なら独り占め、他の人も出してたら分け合おう。

かわいらしい絵柄で、お子様から大人まで楽しんでいただけるカードゲームです。
特に小学生くらいのお子さんやゲーム初心者の方と遊ぶ機会が多い方にお勧めのワイワイと楽しめるゲームに仕上がりました。

boardgame.name: Wheel of Time (7 Books)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Character creation begins with a concept and then the selection of Traits. Instead of using pre-determined Traits, players select which Traits complement their character concept. Sample Traits (which function somewhat like Attributes) include: Agile, Witty, Lithe, and Astute. Traits need not be positive. Players then allocate ten build points to purchase Background, each selection yielding certain benefits. Backgrounds are divided by type, including: Social, Physical, or Skills. One Skill is Talent which comes in a variety of abilities. Perhaps the most powerful Background/Skill/Talent is Channeling which also is complex. Characters may also have Nationality and Childhood Skills. All characters then begin further development at age 14, and the player plots out a Career Path (this may not be completed, but will at least commence). The last step in character creation is outfitting.

Action resolution is divided into different types: Normal Test, Stress Test, or Opposed Test. In all of these, the player rolls 1D20 and one or more D6. The D6 roll "explodes" on a 6. The summed D6 total either adds to, or subtracts from, the D20 roll for a final result which is compared to an action table. Whether the D6 is a bonus or penalty is determined by the type of test and situational modifiers.

boardgame.name: The Wild West (D6)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Wild West is a very simple role-playing game that focuses almost exclusively on firearms combat during the frontier period of the American West. Characters have four Attributes (Strength, Stamina, Smarts, and Speed) and have ten dice distributed among them, with a minimum of 1D and a maximum of 4D. These dice are rolled as a pool whenever the character attempts some action with that Attribute. Characters also have one or more Skills among which thirteen dice are distributed. The game lists eleven "Primary Skills" which must utilize at least seven dice. Characters may have any Secondary Skill the player desires. Most Primary Skills deal with combat: Six Shooter, Rifle, Blade, Fists, Ride, Lasso, Whip, Tracking, Stealth, Ingine Speak, and Gambling.

Action resolution is performed by rolling a D6 dice pool based on either a Skill or an Attribute. Odd results are considered successes. Combat works essentially the same way though it transpires in rounds of limited time and supports initiative.

A printable character sheet in RTF format also is available for download.

boardgame.name: Enemy Coast Ahead: The Doolittle Raid
boardgame.description:
Enemy Coast Ahead: The Doolittle Raid uses the game format to explore the first raid on the Japanese home islands by the United States during World War Two. It is a solitaire game challenging the player to conduct a successful mission where the criteria for success is not purely military. The player must organize, equip, and train a squadron of B-25 medium “Mitchell” bombers to attack a distant and rather dangerous target. The game not only covers the raid from launch to landing, it extends the story on both ends. Threatened from the air and from the sea, the player must do his utmost to strike the Japanese capital, avenging the attack on Pearl Harbor, and then land his aircraft safely. If the raid goes poorly it may boost Japanese morale and deflate the mood in the United States. Getting the B-25s close enough to launch is vital, as is the recovery of aircraft and crewmen, but above all, the player’s main dilemma will be secrecy. The risk is great. Failure could mean the loss of an entire squadron, or worse, the sinking of a precious aircraft carrier. Will the Doolittle Raid add to the dismal news of Pearl Harbor, Guam, Wake Island, and Bataan, or will it signal the turning of the tide?

The History
Washington – April 21, 1942: After two days of rumor prompted by Japanese radio broadcasts, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt finally agrees to a press conference. Deftly avoiding difficult questions, he claims insufficient information to neither confirm nor deny the biggest news story of the four month old war. To placate tenacious journalists, however, he tells the press that the attack on Kobe, Osaka, Nagoya, and Tokyo by United States aircraft, was launched from a mysterious base he would only call “Shangri-La,” an imaginary island from the recently published novel Lost Horizon. His impish grin, if not his words, tell the press that the top secret operation dubbed Special Aviation Project Number One has indeed been a success.

That same day China’s foreign minister hands a telegram to Army Air Corps Chief Hap Arnold. It has taken some time to arrive in Washington, an indication that all may not be well with the mission. Dictated two days ago by the commander of that top secret operation, a distraught Lt. Colonel James Doolittle, it reads:

Mission to bomb Tokyo has been accomplished. On entering China we ran into bad weather and it is feared that all planes crashed.

Telegram in hand, Arnold immediately admits to the commander of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that the mission has failed. No bombers have been recovered. After sending that telegram, Doolittle himself expects a court marshall, confiding to his engineer that they’ll tie him to a desk for the rest of the war, if he’s lucky. Days later he is astonished to learn of his promotion to Brigadier General, and even more so when he is notified that the president recommended the Congressional Medal of Honor.

The Doolittle Raid remains an enigmatic and contradictory episode of World War Two, defying easy interpretation even to this day. Was it a victory or a debacle? Was it a minor footnote in the annals of that war or a significant military event? Was it a desperate bid to avenge the attack on Pearl Harbor, or, a harbinger signaling death and horror soon to visit Japanese cities from the sky?

Narrative Sequence
Much like chapters in a story, the game is organized in six narrative segments, chronologically arranged. Each poses its own set of challenges and prompts decisions that establish the environment and conditions of subsequent chapters.

Planning
Naval
Flight
Over Targets
Recovery
Debriefing

Historical Scenarios
Besides play of the full narrative, the game offers a number of historical dissections, each a scenario focusing on a fragment of the raid. They are also a handy way to learn the game, since each scenario uses only part of the rules. For example, Scenario One covers Doolittle’s flight over Tokyo, using only the 8.5x11 Target Map and the Attack Segment. An alternative scenario looks at a night raid by that flight, as Doolittle originally planned it. After playing one or two small scenarios using only the Attack segment’s rules, a larger scenario can be played adding the Flight segment. Graduate next to an even larger scenario that starts with the Naval segment. In this way a player can learn the game in program fashion, little by little, studying the history of the raid by playing it as he learns.

Player Aid Folders: The game comes with several 11” x 17” bi-fold aids allowing the play of each game segment with minimal study of the rule book. The mapsheet is designed to interlock with other game components, including those play aids, in order to make the player’s experience fluid.

boardgame.name: Karacterz
boardgame.description:
A new epic fighting card game to experience! Build your own fighter, complete with weapons, armor, masteries and origin stories and fight to see who built the best one! Karacterz features 77 unique artworks of 63 artists from 23 countries. Play with a fresh experience every time.

Build your character to specialize in either Magical, Agility (martial arts) or Physical (medieval warfare), have a combination of two of them or all three! Players also build up their character's combat deck to fight with and buff them up with stats. There is no Life Points or Maximum Health in Karacterz so deal as much damage to your opponents as possible! Player with the least amount of damage on them is the victor.

Karacterz is a great game for gamers of all styles and skill levels. This is a perfect game for skilled gamers to play with more casual gamers. Karacterz features many small game mechanics that interact with each other, perfect for experienced gamers, but not necessary a must to win. Those who find the depth of Karacterz overwhelming need not play with every feature to have a great time and beat up their friends!

Playing with a large group? Karacterz features a Teamwork/Betrayal system that guarantees to make group play interesting and more fun! Wanna check out more about Karacterz? Go to our links!

boardgame.name: Penta-Tricks
ペンタトリックス
boardgame.description:
User summary
ペンタトリックス (Penta-Tricks) is a game about the power struggle between aristocrats in the 14th Century France, during the reign of Louis XIV. It combines trick-taking and area-majority.

During the game, changes occur to both the trick-taking trump and the value of areas for area majority points.

The game has Dice in the suit colours set up on a pentagram showing the value 2 at the start. The trick taking follows the normal pattern, with players following the suit lead if possible and the highest card winning. If there is a Trump suit, highest Trump card will win. But after each trick, the dice values change. The winning suit rises by 1 (or 2 if it was Trump). And one of the dice opposite that winning dice falls by 1. After this change, the lowest dice (if any) now becomes Trump.

But this change in dice values also affects the players' scoring. Before the trick winner adjusts the dice values, the losers place one or two cubes against the dice of the suit they played (or its neighbour). NOTE, the winner of the trick does not get to place cubes, but does choose which dice will drop 1 point. At the end of the round, majority cubes score the face value of the dice (except the Trump die), second most gets half rounded down. Tricks won are also worth 2 points each.

So the game becomes more than just winning tricks. Players want to lose tricks so they can place a cube (2 cubes if you lose on a Trump card) and gain majorities. But they also want to win tricks to control Trump or No Trump and lower the points on another dice.

Publisher's summary
ルイ14世時代のフランスが舞台の、貴族達の権力闘争をモチーフにしたゲームです。
トリックテイキングゲームとエリアマジョリティゲームを一つにまとめたような作りになっています。
トリックテイキングの切り札がゲームの途中で変わります。
エリアマジョリティのエリアの価値もゲームの途中で変わります。

boardgame.name: MRPS: Milieu Role Playing System
boardgame.description:
User summary:

MRPS: Milieu Role Playing System is a light-weight and generic, universal role-playing system. It is adaptable to any genre. Characters have Attributes (for example, Strength and Dexterity) and Skills. Skills are divided into Combat and Non-Combat Skills, the only mechanical difference being that Non-Combat Skills are capped at Level +15 proficiency. A Skill Level of 5 is considered "Qualified" while 8 is considered "Expert". When Skills are used the player rolls 1D20 and adds either their Attribute or Skill modifier, whichever is appropriate. This value must match or exceed a target Difficulty.

The Difficulty is derived from the task's narrative description of Easy, Routine, Moderate, Difficult, Formidable, or Impossible. This description is cross-referenced to the campaign style (Realistic, Cinematic, or Heroic) to obtain the Difficulty, which ranged from 5+ to 30+.

Dropout is a humorous take-that card game for up to four players who try to raise their G.P.A in order to graduate.

Unfortunately, there are so many distractions to your studies: parties to attend, movies to watch and beer to drink. Each one of these distractions will lower your G.P.A. However, if you study, do your homework and avoid temptation, you might be able to raise and your G.P.A and graduate!

boardgame.name: Alakazam!
boardgame.description:
Welcome to Robert Houdin’s theater! The most famous magicians in the world come here to prove themselves. You will have to show your skills in card, coin and stage magic. Will you gain the audience’s favor or will this be your last performance?

Alakazam! is a fast-paced card game for 2 to 6 players. Players are dealt a hand of cards with a set of three magic tricks in each. In every turn, each player has to play a card that has a better trick than the one performed by the previous player. They must pass if they don't have a card with a better trick.

The first player to perform all his tricks wins the game.

boardgame.name: All My Friends Are Psycho
boardgame.description:
You always suspected that they were psycho, now it is time to prove it.

In All my Friends are Psycho you become the psychologist and use original designed Rorschach cards to find out just how demented and gross your friends really are.

The Rorschach card deck is set in the middle face down. Flip the same number of cards that you have players, face up.

Without touching the cards, each player chooses an image to analyze keeping their interpretation a secret.

The psychologist picks up the cards and one by one asks each player what they saw. The psychologist has to match the player's interpretation with the correct card.

If the psychologist guesses correctly, both the player and psychologist gets 1 sanity point. If not, they score 1 psycho point.

Each player takes turns being the psychologist. After this the sanity and psycho points are added up. The player that has the closest number of sanity and psycho points (balances out) wins.

The game comes with 27 Rorschach cards and requires a genuine, original (neither genuine nor original) pad and pen.
